Package fr.ens.biologie.generic

Interface SaveableAsText

public interface SaveableAsText

An interface for objects that can be saved as text (in text files or Strings) and later re-loaded with a (static) valueOf() method.

NOTE: classes implementing this interface must implement a static public void valueOf(String) method returning an instance built from its argument. Don't forget that this method can only be implemented in the class it is going to instantiate (i.e. no inheritance).

Author:
Jacques Gignoux - 8 nov. 2018

  • Method Details

    • toSaveableString

      default String toSaveableString​(char[][] blockDelimiters, char[] itemSeparators)

      Produces a String that can be saved to a text file (or any other text-based object) and later re-loaded.

      This method (and all its variants) must return a String that allows to reconstruct the object from it using a valueOf(...) method.

      The general idea is that some external class (a grammar, tokeniser or other thing aware of why the transformation to text is done) will call this method or its variants with two types of arguments, block delimiters and item separators. This way the exact set of tokens to use for a particular application is not hard-coded at this low level but is delegated to a class which contains the overall semantics. Here, we only deal with the semantics of saving/loading a particular object to/from text form.

      Block delimiters come in pairs (an opening and a closing character) while item separators are made of a single char. Item separators should be used to separate items of identical nature (e.g. cells of a table of objects of the same type). Block delimiters should be used to group things of various types together in a meaningful way. The detailed semantics of block delimiters and item separators may vary with implementations The important thing to bear in mind when writing such methods is that the generated String must enable one to reconstruct the object from it.

      The default implementation throws an Exception (i.e., it must be overriden).

      Parameters:
      blockDelimiters - an array of pairs of block delimiters (the second dimension of the array must be 2, with item 0 being the opening block delimiter (e.g. '[') and the item 1 being the closing block delimiter (e.g. ']').
      itemSeparators - an array of separators between repeated items
      Returns:
      the object as a string that allows to reconstruct it with a valueOf(...) method

    • toSaveableString

      default String toSaveableString​(char[] itemSeparators)
      As toSaveableString(char[][],char[]), but with no block delimiters.

      The default implementation calls toSaveableString(char[][],char[]) with null blockDelimiters.

      Parameters:
      itemSeparators - an array of separators between repeated items
      Returns:
      the object as a string that allows to reconstruct it with a valueOf(...) method

    • toSaveableString

      default String toSaveableString​(char[][] blockDelimiters)
      As toSaveableString(char[][],char[]), but with no separators

      The default implementation calls toSaveableString(char[][],char[]) with null itemSeparators.

      Parameters:
      blockDelimiters - an array of pairs of block delimiters (the second dimension of the array must be 2, with item 0 being the opening block delimiter (e.g. '[') and the item 1 being the closing block delimiter (e.g. ']').
      Returns:
      the object as a string that allows to reconstruct it with a valueOf(...) method

    • toSaveableString

      default String toSaveableString()
      As toSaveableString(char[][],char[]), but with no separators nor delimiters.

      The default implementation calls toSaveableString(char[][],char[]) with null blockDelimiters and itemSeparators. Overwrite it if you want to use standard default delimiters and separators.

      Returns:
      the object as a string that allows to reconstruct it with a valueOf(...) method

    • toSaveableString

      default String toSaveableString​(char[] blockDelimiters, char itemSeparator)
      As toSaveableString(char[][],char[]), but with only one pair of block delimiters and one item separator
      Parameters:
      blockDelimiters - an array of 2 chars with item 0 being the opening block delimiter (e.g. '<') and the item 1 being the closing block delimiter (e.g. '>').
      itemSeparator - a separator between repeated items
      Returns:
      the object as a string that allows to reconstruct it with a valueOf(...) method

    • toSaveableString

      default String toSaveableString​(char startBlockDelimiter, char endBlockDelimiter, char itemSeparator)
      As toSaveableString(char[][],char[]), but with only one pair of block delimiters and one item separator
      Parameters:
      startBlockDelimiter - the opening block delimiter
      endBlockDelimiter - the closing block delimiter
      itemSeparator - the item separator
      Returns:
      the object as a string that allows to reconstruct it with a valueOf(...) method

    • toSaveableString

      default String toSaveableString​(char startBlockDelimiter, char endBlockDelimiter)
      As toSaveableString(char[][],char[]), but with only one pair of block delimiters and no item separator

      The default implementation calls toSaveableString(char[][],char[]) with null itemSeparators.

      Parameters:
      startBlockDelimiter - the opening block delimiter
      endBlockDelimiter - the closing block delimiter
      Returns:
      the object as a string that allows to reconstruct it with a valueOf(...) method

    • toSaveableString

      default String toSaveableString​(char itemSeparator)
      As toSaveableString(char[][],char[]), but with no block delimiters and one item separator

      The default implementation calls toSaveableString(char[][],char[]) with null blockDelimiters.

      Parameters:
      itemSeparator - the item separator
      Returns:
      the object as a string that allows to reconstruct it with a valueOf(...) method
